nodes.text: , you can use the historical average return of a security as its expected return. With these expected returns, you can compute the
The weighted average of the expected returns of the investments in a portfolio, where the weights correspond to the portfolio weights.
, which is simply the weighted average of the expected returns of the investments within it, using the portfolio weights:

nodes.text: We started by stating that you can describe a portfolio by its weights. These weights are used in computing both a portfolio’s return and its expected return.

leaves.text: The relative investment in your portfolio

nodes.text: Suppose you invest $10,000 in Boeing (BA) stock, and $30,000 in Merck (MRK) stock. You expect a return of 10% for Boeing and 16% for Merck. What is the expected return for your portfolio?
You have a total of $40,000 invested:

data.mathML: <math display="block"><mtable columnalign="left"><mtr><mtd><mn>$</mn><mn>10,000</mn><mo>/</mo><mn>$</mn><mn>40,000</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>25</mn><mo>%</mo><mtext> in Boeing and</mtext><mo>:</mo><mspace width="0.7em"/><mi>E</mi><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><msub><mi>R</mi><mrow><mi>B</mi><mi>A</mi></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn><mo>%</mo></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mn>$</mn><mn>30,000</mn><mo>/</mo><mn>$</mn><mn>40,000</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>75</mn><mo>%</mo><mtext> in Merck and</mtext><mo>:</mo><mspace width="0.7em"/><mi>E</mi><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><msub><mi>R</mi><mrow><mtext mathvariant="italic">MRK</mtext></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>16</mn><mo>%</mo></mtd></mtr></mtable></math>
data.alt: StartLayout 1st Row  Number dollar sign 10,000 divided by Number dollar sign 40,000 equals 25 percent sign in Boeing and colon upper E left bracket upper R Subscript upper B upper A Baseline right bracket equals 10 percent sign 2nd Row  Number dollar sign 30,000 divided by Number dollar sign 40,000 equals 75 percent sign in Merck and colon upper E left bracket upper R Subscript italic MRK Baseline right bracket equals 16 percent sign EndLayout

nodes.text: , compute the expected return on your whole portfolio by multiplying the expected returns of the stocks in your portfolio by their respective portfolio weights.
The expected return on your portfolio is:

data.alt: StartLayout 1st Row 1st Column upper E left bracket upper R Subscript upper P Baseline right bracket 2nd Column equals 3rd Column w Subscript italic BA Baseline upper E left bracket upper R Subscript italic BA Baseline right bracket plus w Subscript italic MRK Baseline upper E left bracket upper R Subscript italic MRK Baseline right bracket 2nd Row 1st Column upper E left bracket upper R Subscript upper P Baseline right bracket 2nd Column equals 3rd Column 0.25 times 10 percent sign plus 0.75 times 16 percent sign equals 14.5 percent sign EndLayout

nodes.text: The importance of each stock for the expected return of the overall portfolio is determined by the relative amount of money you have invested in it. Most (75%) of your money is invested in Merck, so the overall expected return of the portfolio is much closer to Merck’s expected return than it is to Boeing’s.
What do the weights in a portfolio tell us?
How is the expected return of a portfolio related to the expected returns of the stocks in the portfolio?

stage.text: Expected Portfolio Return As we showed in  Chapter 11 , you can use the historical average return of a security as its expected return. With these expected returns, you can compute the  expected return of a portfolio , which is simply the weighted average of the expected returns of the investments within it, using the portfolio weights: (12.3)  We started by stating that you can describe a portfolio by its weights. These weights are used in computing both a portfolio’s return and its expected return.  Table 12.1  summarizes these concepts.  Example 12.2 Portfolio Expected Return Problem Suppose you invest $10,000 in Boeing (BA) stock, and $30,000 in Merck (MRK) stock. You expect a return of 10% for Boeing and 16% for Merck. What is the expected return for your portfolio? Solution Plan You have a total of $40,000 invested:  Using  Eq. 12.3 , compute the expected return on your whole portfolio by multiplying the expected returns of the stocks in your portfolio by their respective portfolio weights. Execute The expected return on your portfolio is:  Evaluate The importance of each stock for the expected return of the overall portfolio is determined by the relative amount of money you have invested in it. Most (75%) of your money is invested in Merck, so the overall expected return of the portfolio is much closer to Merck’s expected return than it is to Boeing’s. Concept Check What do the weights in a portfolio tell us? How is the expected return of a portfolio related to the expected returns of the stocks in the portfolio?
